Chapter 5, Part 4: Discrimination of Action, on relinquishing the prÄtimoká¹£a restraint, etc. Thus far the prÄtimoká¹£a restraint, etc., have been explained. Now the relinquishment of the prÄtimoká¹£a restraint, etc., will be explained next.
First, how is the prÄtimoká¹£a restraint relinquished?
Verse:
The prÄtimoká¹£a restraint is relinquished by intentionally abandoning it, death,
The arising of both sexes, severing the wholesome roots, and the end of the night.
Some say it is by committing a grave offense, others say by the Dharma's disappearance;
The KaÅ›mÄ«rans say it is like incurring debt by committing two offenses.
Discussion:
The term taming indicates a different name for the restraint, because it can tame the faculties.
The prÄtimoká¹£a restraint is relinquished by five causes:

First, by intentionally abandoning it. That is, by not cherishing the intention for the restraint, for the sake of abandoning the precepts, one generates a contradictory expression of action towards one who understands.
It is not only by the arising of the thought of abandoning the precepts, because the thought of obtaining the precepts is powerless.
Also, abandoning in a dream is not valid.ğŸ”½It is not only by the arising of the differences in the manifest actions, because abandoning by anger, insanity, etc. is not valid.
It is not only by the arising of the thought and the manifest action toward animals, etc., because abandoning is not valid.
Second, by death, because the precepts are obtained by the power of the increase of the common portion.
Third, by the simultaneous arising of the two organs, because when the body changes, the mind also changes, and also because one with two organs is not superior.
Fourth, by the annihilation of the wholesome roots that are the cause, because the manifest actions, unmanifest actions, and the arising thought are annihilated.
This is the meaning of the annihilation of the causes of these precepts. The precepts for the duration of life are abandoned by the above four conditions.

The precepts of the upavÄsa are also abandoned by the end of the night, because the precepts of the upavÄsa are abandoned by the above four conditions and by the end of the night, because the period is exceeded.
When the night ends means when the dawn appears, this is generally accepted by the masters.

Regarding these five causes of relinquishing the prÄtimoká¹£a restraint, some other schools hold that when one commits a grave offense leading to an infraction, one relinquishes the restraint of leaving the household life.
Some other schools hold that when the true Dharma perishes, all prÄtimoká¹£a restraints are not relinquished, because all the precepts, boundary-marking karman, and the holy teachings all cease.
The masters of the Abhidharma say:
At that time, although there is no obtaining of the restraint that has not yet been obtained, there is no relinquishment of the previously obtained restraint.
The KÄÅ›mÄ«ri VaibhÄá¹£ikas, who hold the teachings and principles in their minds, say:
When one commits any one of the fundamental offenses, all the restraints are not necessarily relinquished.
However, one who commits a grave offense has two kinds of names: one is called one who possesses morality, and the other is called one who violates the precepts.
If one repents and confesses the offense, one is only called one who possesses morality.
It is like a wealthy person who owes another a debt being called both wealthy and one who owes a debt. If the debt is repaid, he is then called only wealthy.
This is also so for the relinquishment of precepts.
How are the two types of restraint of dhyana and pure precepts relinquished?
Verse:
The wholesome dharmas born of dhyana are relinquished by changing stages or regressing, etc.
All pure wholesome dharmas are relinquished by attaining fruition or regressing.
Treatise:
The wholesome dharmas associated with the stages of dhyana are relinquished by two causes:
First, by changing stages, referring to being born above or below;
Second, by regressing, referring to regressing from superior samÄdhi.
When relinquishing the same life-stream and when free from defilements, one also relinquishes the warmth, etc., and the fixed samÄdhi of the stage of regression.
In order to include these, the word etc. is again used.
Just as wholesome dharmas of the form realm are relinquished by changing stages, regressing, and being free from defilements, so it is for the three formless realms.
Pure wholesome dharmas are relinquished by two kinds of causes:
First, one abandons the previous path by attaining the fruit. Second, one abandons the superior paths by falling back.
This is either the fruit or the fruit of a superior fruit.
Here I should make a brief distinction.

If one abandons the path of insight and the path of insight into the nature of things, one should know that it is only by attaining the fruit, not by falling back, because the fruit of the path of insight into the nature of things is also necessarily without falling back.
The faculties that have been cultivated by falling back also have the meaning of falling back.
For the immovable dharma, both learners and post-learners are both without. The remaining uncontaminated [precepts] may have both kinds.
Thus far, the abandonment of various precepts has been explained.
How is the non-restraint abandoned?
Verse:
Non-restraint is abandoned by death, obtaining precepts, or the appearance of two genders.
Treatise:
Non-restraint is abandoned by three causes:
First, by death, because the basis is abandoned. Because the power of the same species obtains the precepts.

Second, by obtaining morality, that is, if one obtains the morality of individual liberation, or if one obtains the morality of meditation, then the evil morality is abandoned, because the power of the antidote is superior and one abandons the non-restraint.
Third, by the two organs of the continuity arising together, because at that time the basis changes.
When one who is unrestrained receives the precepts of the upavÄsa and, at the end of the night, abandons the restraint, does one obtain the non-restraint, or is one called neutral?
Other masters say:
One obtains the non-restraint, because the evil intention is not permanently abandoned, just as when a heated iron cools and turns red, and then turns blue.
Other masters say:
If one does not commit again, there is no condition for one to obtain the non-restraint, because the non-restraint is obtained based on the expression.

The former explanation is reasonable, because at the time of first receiving the precepts, the evil intention is not permanently abandoned, and the evil morality arises again based on the previous expression.
How is the neutral indeterminate form abandoned again?
Verse:
In the middle, by the power of feeling, by action, by the end of life.
The treatise says:
The indeterminate form of the middle is abandoned by six conditions:
First, by the abandonment of the mind of acceptance. This refers to the vow to always respectfully pay homage to stupas and chant praises at a certain time.
Now, one thinks:
I will not do it again later.
Their intention ceases from this point on, because they abandon their original intention.
Or else, they do something else whose power is stronger, which contradicts the previous action. The original intention ceases, and the indeterminate form is cut off.

Second, by the abandonment of power. This refers to the indeterminate form attracted by the power of pure faith and afflictions. When the limit of their power is cut off, the indeterminate form is abandoned, like an arrow shot or a potter's wheel.
Therefore, the teachers say:

Because it is attracted and produced by the power of the initial thought, even though one abandons the added effort and the intention, the noninformative may still continue to function for the rest of oneâ€™s life. This is also the case when one arouses a very strong fetter and strikes a bird or beast.
Or, one may have previously established a limit, such as, â€œI will do this for a certain period of time,â€ and when the force of the limit is exhausted, the noninformative is also cut off.

Third, one abandons the noninformative by cutting off the action that constitutes the basis for it, that is, even though one does not abandon the fundamental attitude that constitutes the basis, one no longer performs the action that was undertaken, with the exception of the case where one forgets to perform it.
This is because this noninformative action is generated by the added effort of a vow, and when the added effort is cut off, the noninformative action is also cut off.

Fourth, one abandons the noninformative by cutting off the thing that constitutes the basis for it, that is, one gives up a gift to a caitya, a garden, a forest, or other thing, or one cuts off a net or other device that one had previously established. The noninformative action that was generated by that thing is cut off when the thing is destroyed.
Fifth, one abandons the noninformative by cutting off the life that constitutes the basis for it, because the support has changed.
Sixth, by the severing of the organ, that is, when one generates the practice of severing good or evil, one abandons the nonmanifest action attracted by that organ.
When one severs the nonconcentrated good or evil nonmanifest action of the realm of desire, one abandons it by the arising of the antidote.
The word organ here refers to the good or evil organs.
The word severing refers to the severing of the practice.
How does one abandon the good nonmaterial dharmas of the realm of desire and all defiled dharmas of the formless realm?
Verse:
One abandons the good of the realm of desire and the formless by severing the organs and being born in a higher realm.
One abandons all the defiled of the formless realm by the arising of the antidote.
Commentary:
All good dharmas of the realm of desire and nonmaterial dharmas are abandoned by two causes:
first, by severing the roots of good; second, by being born in a higher realm.
It should be said that a small part is also abandoned by separation from passion, just as the organ of sorrow, etc., and nonmaterial good dharmas.
All defiled dharmas of the three realms that are not form are abandoned by one condition, namely, the arising of the path of elimination.
If the path of elimination of a certain class arises, one abandons the passions and their associates in that class.
Which sentient beings have good or bad moral discipline?
Verse:
Bad moral discipline is absent in the north, in the two eunuchs, and in those with two organs.
Moral discipline also exists in the heavens. Only humans have all three kinds.
In the desire heavens and the form realm, there is moral discipline of the dhyanas.
Pure and formless realms, excluding the middle concentration and non-perception.
Discussion:
Non-discipline does not exist in the human realm, but it is absent in the northern continent. It exists only in the three directions.
Within the three directions, it is also absent in the continent of Kuru and in pandakas.
Those with two organs also have moral discipline.
That is to say, in the human realm, excluding those previously excluded, and it also exists in the heavens. Therefore, moral discipline exists in the two destinies.
However, only humans possess all three kinds of moral precepts, namely, the moral precepts of individual liberation, the moral precepts of meditation, and the moral precepts of the pure precepts.
If one is born in the heavens of the desire realm or in the form realm, one may obtain the moral precepts of meditation. However, in the heaven of non-perception, one only possesses them.
If one is born in the formless realm, neither of them exists.
The moral precepts of the pure precepts also exist in the formless realm.

If one is born in the heavens of the desire realm or in the form realm, excluding the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception and the heaven of non-perception, one may obtain the moral precepts of the pure precepts.

If one is born in the formless realm, one only possesses them, because one has no form. They definitely do not manifest. Because one obtains the pure precepts of lower stages when one is born in higher stages,
We have distinguished the different natures and characteristics of the various actions. We will now explain the various actions indicated in the sÅ«tras.
The sÅ«tras say that there are three kinds of actions: good, bad, and indeterminate.
What are their characteristics?
A verse says:
Actions that are peaceful, not peaceful, and neither are called good, bad, and indeterminate.
The treatise says:
The term good is used to refer to all actions that are tranquil, because they can obtain a pleasant retribution and nirvana, and temporarily or permanently save one from suffering.
The term bad is used to refer to all actions that are not tranquil, because they can attract an unpleasant retribution, and because they are able to obstruct the path to nirvana.
The term indeterminate is used to refer to actions that are neither of the first two kinds, because they cannot be said to be good or bad.
Also, a scripture says:
There are three kinds of action, meritorious, nonmeritorious, etc.
What are their characteristics?
A verse says:ğŸ”½Meritorious, nonmeritorious, and unmoving; good actions of the realm of desire are called meritorious.
Bad actions are called nonmeritorious; good actions of the upper two realms are called unmoving.

They are so called because their results and actions are unmoving in their place in the realms.ğŸ”½The treatise says that good actions of the realm of desire are called meritorious because they are opposed to nonmeritorious and attract a pleasant retribution.
Bad actions are called nonmeritorious because they attract an unpleasant retribution and are opposed to meritorious actions.
The two wholesome minds of the two upper realms are called unmoving.
Hasnâ€™t the World Honored One said that the first three concentrations are all called moving?
The sages say that in these there is the moving of investigation, analysis, joy, pleasure, and feeling.
Because in the first three concentrations the calamities of investigation, analysis, etc., have not yet ceased, they are called moving.
The Sutra says that the unmoving is so called because it can induce an unmoving retribution.
How can a moving concentration induce an unmoving retribution?

Even though there is movement in this concentration due to calamities, still, as far as the retribution of action is concerned, it is not the same as the realm of desire, which is moving. Therefore it is called unmoving.
This means that in the realm of desire, action that fills other destinies may be received in other destinies by the power of special conditions.

This is because there are actions that can induce external and internal wealth, status, form, size, color, strength, pleasure, etc., that should mature in the heavens, etc., but by the power of special conditions, the action is attracted and transformed and the action matures in humans, etc.

As for the actions of the other stages and realms of form and formlessness, it is impossible to transform them into retribution in other realms and stages, because the place of retribution of action is fixed and unchangeable and because the stage of samÄdhi includes them and they are not scattered and moved.
On the basis of this interpretation, the name immovable is established.
You should know that in this context, because of ignorance of the relationship of cause and effect, one creates nonmeritorious action.
Because nonmeritorious action is purely defiled, it must be based on the ignorance that is the continuity of the seeds of the two obstacles.
Because of the presence of this ignorance, one is unable to understand and believe in the relationship of cause and effect and therefore produces various nonmeritorious actions.
Because of ignorance of the truth, one creates meritorious and immovable actions.
The truth refers to the four noble truths.

If one is ignorant of them, the various ordinary beings can still produce good thoughts and can still produce them intermittently. As a result of this power, one does not understand as it really is that the nature of the three realms is suffering, and one produces meritorious and immovable actions as causes for future lives.

If one has already seen the truths, then this is not the case. The power of the prior practice of the vehicle gradually causes one to become free from the passions. At that time, one is born in the realm of desire, the realm of form, and the formless realm, respectively.
Also, a scripture says:
There are three kinds of action, namely, action that produces pleasant feeling, etc.
What are their characteristics?
A verse says:ğŸ”½Good action up to the third stage is conducive to pleasant feeling.
Bad action is conducive to unpleasant feeling. Good action in the upper stages is conducive to neither.
Others say that the lower stages also have this, because the retribution of the middle stages is attracted.
Also, it is admitted that these three kinds of action are not matured before or after.
There are five kinds of feeling in relation to action, namely, by nature, by association,
by object, by retribution, and by manifestation.

The treatise says that among good actions, from the realm of desire up to the third trance state, it is called action that produces pleasant feeling, because all pleasant feelings are only up to this point.
Bad action is called action that produces unpleasant feeling.

Good action of the fourth trance state and the formless realm is said to be that which produces the feeling of neither pleasure nor suffering, because above that there is no feeling of pleasure or suffering.
You should understand that these actions not only produce feelings as results, they also produce the requisites of those feelings.
Feeling and its requisites are called feeling here, and the name feeling is given in general to what is transformed into desire.
Is it admitted that there is action that produces neither pleasure nor suffering in the lower stages or not?
Other masters say that
it also exists in the lower stages, because if there were no action in the intermediate state of trance, there would be no suffering or pleasure.
There is another proof: according to a treatise,
Is there any threefold action the results of which are not experienced first, later, or at the same time?
It is said that

there is, namely, form that is action that produces pleasure, the mind and mental activities that are action that produces suffering, and the dharmas not associated with the mind that are action that produces neither pleasure nor suffering.
This proves that action that produces neither pleasure nor suffering also exists in the lower stages.
These three kinds of karma do not exist apart from the realm of desire, because they are all matured simultaneously. This is not a definite proof.
However, it should be determined that there is karma that is neither good nor bad in the lower stages. This should be understood in accordance with the extensive discussion in the SatpÄdÄbhidharma.
Is this karma good or bad?
Some say:
It is good but inferior, and it cannot be specifically indicated but can be generally said to exist.

Among all good karmas, there may be one kind that can produce pleasant feelings and the requisites for feelings, or there may be one kind that cannot produce both. One should know that this karma that benefits pleasant feelings is called karma that produces pleasant feelings, like the place that is favorable to horses.
Or, this karma is able to experience pleasure, and therefore it is called karma that produces pleasant feelings, like the scattered flowers that are favorable to bathing.
Karma that produces the other feelings should be understood in the same way.
This karma is not only the retribution of feelings. How is it that it is generally called karma that produces feelings?
Because all retributions that are produced by karma as a cause are similar to feelings and are called feelings.
Why is this so?
Because they all benefit or harm the body, or are neutral, just like water, fire, etc., benefit, harm, or are neutral to tree branches, etc.
Moreover, there are five kinds of conformity to feeling, which are summarized as follows:
First, the intrinsic nature of conformity to feeling, which refers to the nature of feelings themselves. As a sutra says:
When experiencing pleasant feelings, one accurately knows that one is experiencing pleasant feelings, and so on at length.
Second, conformity to feeling through association, which refers to all contacts. As a sutra says:
Contacts that conform to pleasant feelings, and so on at length.
Third, conformity to feeling through objects, which refers to all objects. As a sutra says:
When the eye sees forms, one only experiences the forms and does not experience craving for forms, and so on at length. Because forms, etc., are the objects of feelings.
Fourth, conformity to feeling through karmic retribution, which refers to karma that produces karmic retribution. As a sutra says:
Karma that conforms to pleasant feelings, and so on at length.
The fifth is feeling that is experienced, that is, feeling that is actually occurring, as a scripture says:
When one experiences a pleasant feeling, two feelings are eliminated.
When this pleasant feeling is present, no other feeling can experience this pleasant feeling.
But when the substance of the pleasant feeling is present, it is said that feeling experiences pleasant feeling, because there are many kinds of feelings that are experienced.
Although the results of action are not all feeling, still it is possible to establish the general name â€œfeelingâ€ for them.

That is, the form and the dissociated forces that are the results of good action as cause are able to generate pleasant feeling that has them as objects, because they are the pleasant feelings that are grasped and appropriated, and because they are the desirable results that accord with the experience of pleasant feeling. They are also called pleasant feeling.
Consequently, although the results of good action are not pleasant feeling, they are called the results of action that accords with pleasant feeling because they accord with pleasant feeling.
The results of action that accords with pleasant feeling, unpleasant feeling, and neither, should be understood in the same way.
What are the characteristics of the certainty and uncertainty of these three kinds of action?
Verse:
This has definite and indefinite [retribution], definite [retribution] is of three kinds, such as that which is experienced in the present life, etc.
Or it is said that there are five kinds of karma, other masters say there are four propositions.
The treatise says:

It should be known that the above-mentioned karma that accords with pleasant feeling, etc. each has definite and indefinite differences. It is called indefinite because the retribution is not definite.

That is to say, karma that accords with pleasant feeling is not necessarily definitely matured. If it is matured, it must be experienced as pleasant retribution. The explanation for the other two kinds of karma is also like this.
Definite [retribution] is further of three kinds:
1. That which is experienced in the present life, 2. That which is experienced in the next life, 3. That which is experienced in a subsequent life.
These three kinds of definite karma definitely induce retribution. Together with the previous indefinite [karma], they form a total of four kinds.

Some people want to make the indefinite karma experienced have two kinds, namely, that which is definite and indefinite in its retribution. Together with the three kinds of definite karma, they form a total of five kinds.
The UpÄyikÄ masters say that karma has four propositions:

First, there is karma whose time period is definite but whose retribution is indefinite, namely, the three types of karma that are conducive to the present life, etc., which are not definitely able to obtain retribution.
Second, there is karma whose retribution is definite but whose time period is indefinite, namely, indeterminate karma that is definitely able to obtain retribution.
Third, there is karma whose two aspects are both definite, namely, karma that is conducive to the present life, etc., which is definitely able to obtain retribution.
Fourth, there is karma whose two aspects are both indefinite, namely, indeterminate karma that is not definitely able to obtain retribution.

They say that all karma in total is made up of eight types, namely, that which is conducive to the present life and so on, which are each definite or indefinite, and indeterminate karma, which is also of two types.
Among the distinctions of karma that have been discussed, a verse says:
Four kinds of good karma can be performed together. Only three kinds of karma can attract rebirth in the realm of similar kind.
In all realms, four kinds of karma are performed. In hell, good karma excludes that which is conducive to the present life.
Firmly abiding in the stage of separation from desire, ordinary beings do not perform karma that produces rebirth.
Holy beings do not perform karma that produces rebirth or karma that is conducive to the next life. They also do not retrogress from the desire realm or the peak of existence.
The treatise says:

The SÅ«tra says that there are four kinds of karma: that which is to be experienced in the present life, that which is to be experienced after rebirth, that which is to be experienced in some subsequent period, and that which is indeterminate. The first three are definite, and the fourth is indefinite. The first three are divided into three kinds, and the fourth is added to make four. This is a good explanation.

The SÅ«tra says that there are four kinds of action: action whose retribution is to be experienced in the present life, etc. The four kinds of action are distinguished in order to show that action to be experienced in the present life, etc., is sometimes determinate and sometimes indeterminate. Action whose retribution is to be experienced in the present life is of three kinds, according to whether its retribution is to be experienced in the present life, in the next life, or in some subsequent life. Action whose retribution is to be experienced in the present life is of three kinds, according to whether its retribution is to be experienced in the present life, in the next life, or in some subsequent life. Action whose retribution is to be experienced in the next life is of three kinds, according to whether its retribution is to be experienced in the present life, in the next life, or in some subsequent life. Action whose retribution is to be experienced in some subsequent life is of three kinds, according to whether its retribution is to be experienced in the present life, in the next life, or in some subsequent life. Action whose retribution is indeterminate is of three kinds, according to whether its retribution is to be experienced in the present life, in the next life, or in some subsequent life. Thus there are twelve kinds of action.ğŸ”½But it is impossible for the time of retribution to be indeterminate when the nature of the retribution is determinate. The time of retribution is determined when the retribution is determinate.
But how can the time be indeterminate when the nature of the retribution is indeterminate?
The time of retribution is determined when the retribution is indeterminate, because the retribution will be experienced in the present life, etc.
Can the four kinds of action be accomplished at the same time?ğŸ”½Yes.
How?
When a person sends three messengers to kill three people, and at the same time has sexual relations with the wife of one of them, then the four kinds of action are accomplished at the same time.

Only three can be attracted, excluding karma to be experienced in the present life, because karma to be experienced in the present life necessarily arises in dependence on the homogeneous characteristis attracted by previous karma, and because it necessarily produces results in the present life.
In what realms and destinies can one create how many kinds of karma?
In all realms and destinies, good and bad, one may create the four kinds as appropriate. This is the general explanation.
If we discuss specific prohibitions, in the hells, good karma excludes that to be experienced in the present life, because there is no pleasant result.
The other three can be created.
In the destinies of nonretrogression, the name is firm. If ordinary beings are free from passion, they exclude karma to be experienced after rebirth, and the other three can be created.

Holy teachings exclude both karma to be experienced after rebirth and that to be experienced in a later life, and the other two can be created.ğŸ”½Ordinary beings who do not retrogress, if free from passion, are not able to be reborn immediately in those destinies, and therefore they must exclude karma to be experienced after rebirth.
Because they necessarily return to lower destinies after death in the upper destinies, they may create karma to be experienced in a later life.

If the noble one does not retrogress from the stage of detachment, it is impossible for him to be reborn in this stage. Therefore, the two types of karma that are conducive to rebirth and conducive to continuation are excluded. In the place where one is reborn, one can create karma that is conducive to the experience of the present life. One can also create indeterminate karma. There is no prohibition against this in any place.

However, if the noble one has already become detached from the realm of desire and the peak of existence, even though he retrogresses, he still does not create karma that is conducive to rebirth or conducive to continuation. This is because one who retrogresses from this stage necessarily retrogresses from the fruit.
One who has retrograded from the fruit will certainly not die and be reborn in the realm of desire. He will regain the original fruit.
Does one who is in the intermediate state of existence also create karma?
He also creates karma.
How?
The verse states:
In the desire realm, one in the intermediate state can create twenty-two kinds of karma.
All are included in karma conducive to the experience of the present life, because the species and the stage are the same.
The treatise states:
In the desire realm, one who is in the intermediate state can create twenty-two kinds of karma.
This refers to the five stages of the intermediate state of existence, the five stages of being in the womb, and the five stages after leaving the womb.
The five stages in the womb are kalala, arbuda, peÅ›in, ghana, and praÅ›ÄkhÄ.
The five stages outside the womb are infant, child, youth, adult, and elder.
These eleven stages are included in the first stage of life.
In the intermediate state of existence, one can create definite and indefinite karma for the intermediate state, up to the ability to create the two karmas for the stage of old age.
One should understand it is also like this.

One should know that the eleven kinds of definite karma created in the intermediate state are all included in karma to be experienced in the present life, because the class and homogeneous character are without distinction.

That is to say, this intermediate state of existence and the ten states of its own class are drawn by one karma. For this reason, karma to be experienced in the intermediate state is not explained separately, because it is drawn by the karma to be experienced in the next life, etc.

The class and homogeneous character refers to the class of humans, etc., which is neither a realm nor a birth, because the intermediate state and the actual state have different homogeneous characters in terms of realms and births.
What are the characteristics of karma that is definitely experienced?
Verse:
Due to heavy afflictions, pure mind, and constant performance,
Arising in the field of merit, the karma of harming one's parents is definite.
The treatise says:
If the karma one creates is due to heavy afflictions, or a pure mind, or is constantly performed, or arises in a field of superior merit.
The field of merit refers to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, or superior individuals who have realized worldly and transcendent virtues.

Even if one does not have heavy afflictions or a pure mind, or does not perform it constantly, if one creates good or bad karma, or if one harms one's parents while giving rise to a lesser fetter, all such karma is included in definite karma.
Other masters say:

If it is created with a very sharp intention, or if it is created and then a joyful mind arises, or if it is practiced frequently at all times, or if it arises from the power of superior vows and the power of things, then it is all definitely karma with results in the present life.
What are its characteristics?
Verse:
Due to the superiority of field, intention, and certainty in producing retribution,
Karma that obtains the stage of permanent separation definitely produces results in the present life.

Discussion:ğŸ”½As for the superiority of field, it is heard that there are bhiká¹£us who, in the assembly of monks, speak woman's words, and in an instant they transform into women. There are many such stories.
As for the superiority of intention, it is heard that there are eunuchs who rescue and liberate cows, and in an instant they transform into men. There are many such stories.

Or there is another kind of action that also obtains a present retribution, namely, that which is done by one who is born in a certain stage and who is eternally separated from the passions of that stage. This action must necessarily be retributed in the present life, because he will not be reborn in that stage.

For example, when arhats and nonreturners have already done this kind of action before they are separated from the passions, they are now separated from the passions and the action is accomplished as retribution in the present life. What kind of action is this?
It is action whose retribution is definite.
You should know that the action referred to in this discussion is action whose retribution is definite, not action whose time of retribution is definite.

If there is any other state in which action is definite in retribution, then it is definitely not the case that one is eternally separated from the passions, and one must experience the retribution of the action in another state.
If the retribution is not definite, then because one is eternally separated from the passions, one does not experience the retribution.
When nonreturners and arhats fall back and generate the passions of the three realms, they definitely do not generate the lower realm, because they are definitely in nirvÄá¹‡a.
Action whose retribution is definite is all accomplished as retribution in the present life. The rest are to be discussed according to the circumstances.
In what field does one create karma that is definitely experienced in the present life?
Verse:
In the Buddha, the foremost of the Sangha, and in the attainment of cessation and the absence of conflict,
In the cultivation of kindness and insight, and in leaving the world, the results of beneficial and harmful karma are experienced in the present life.
Commentary:
In such a category of field of merit, one creates good or evil karma that is definitely experienced in the present life.
The field of merit refers to the Buddha and the foremost of the Sangha.
From the perspective of the distinctions in individuals, there are five:
First, emerging from the attainment of cessation. This refers to the attainment of mental tranquility in this concentration, because this concentration is tranquil and resembles nirvana.

If one first gives rise to the mind after emerging from this concentration, it is like one who enters nirvana and then emerges again. The supreme tranquil merit adorns one's body and becomes the basis for the growth of sincere and pure thoughts.

Second, when one emerges from the concentration of non-conflict, one is able to forever eliminate the continuity of all afflictions and calamities. Having the capacity to take all sentient beings as objects, the boundless superior intention and merit of non-conflict accumulate and permeate the body. When one emerges from this concentration, the continuity of that mind is not overcome by any worldly concentrated or unconcentrated mind, and it is the supreme field of merit for both virtue and non-virtue.

Third, when one emerges from the concentration of loving-kindness, this concentration has as its object the boundless sentient beings, and the superior intention to benefit and bring peace accumulates and permeates the body.
When one emerges from this concentration, the body that is cultivated by the boundless supreme merits of the conditioned realm continues and transforms, and is able to give rise to superior actions.

Fourth, when one emerges from the path of seeing, this path is able to transcend what cannot be transcended by the one-sided, beginningless transmigrationâ€”the fundamental cycle of birth and death of the three realms. When one emerges from this path, there is a superior, pure body that continues and is born, able to give rise to superior actions.
The fifth is that which emerges from the path of cultivation, because in this path one is able to transcend the root of one part of birth and death. The rest is as previously explained.

In each of these first emerging states, one rides on the power of the superior merits cultivated previously, and the mind still looks back and remembers them without abandoning them. The faculties are tranquil and especially different from usual. No worldly or supramundane definite or indefinite merit can surpass or overpower them, therefore these five are called fields of merit.
If there is a deed of harm or benefit in these, this deed will definitely be able to bring about the immediate fruit.

If one emerges from other concentrations or other fruits, because the previously cultivated concentration is not superior, and the afflictions eliminated by cultivation are not ultimately exhausted, therefore that continuum is not a superior field of merit. In the fruit of retribution, feeling is the most superior.
Now we should consider, are there any deeds that only bring about retribution as mental feeling, or that bring about bodily feeling but not mental feeling?
There are.
How so?
In verse it is said:
The results of good karma without vitarka are said to be only mental feeling.
Evil karma only produces bodily feeling. This is the difference between feeling and karma.
The treatise says:
Good karma without vitarka refers to good karma from the intermediate concentration up to the peak of existence.
Among them, that which can attract feeling as its retribution should be known as only producing mental feeling, not bodily feeling, because in those stages there is no bodily feeling.
Bodily feeling is definitely associated with vitarka. Karma without vitarka does not produce results with vitarka.
Evil karma that can produce feeling should be known as only producing bodily feeling, not mental feeling, because evil causes have suffering as their result.
Suffering in the mental realm is definitely called worry. Worry feeling is definitely not included in the results of retribution. Therefore, evil karma only produces bodily feeling.

If it is held that the faculty of worry is definitely not retribution, then the mental confusion produced by various sentient beings - in which consciousness is it produced? What causes does it respond to? On what basis does it arise? Is it not retribution?
A verse says:
The mind is only insane in the sixth consciousness, and arises from the retribution of karma,
and from fear, harm, and sorrow, except in Uttarakuru, and in the desire realm.
The treatise says:

The mind of sentient beings is only insane in the sixth consciousness. If it were in the five consciousnesses, it would definitely not be a deranged mind, because the group of five consciousnesses is without discrimination.
For what reason do sentient beings have a deranged mind?
It arises from the retribution of the karma of sentient beings.
From what kind of karma does it arise?

It is said that it is caused by using drugs and spells to make others' minds deranged, or by making others drink what they do not want, such as poison or alcohol, or by displaying awesome power to frighten birds and beasts, or by setting a great fire to burn mountains and marshes, or by digging pits and traps to ensnare sentient beings, or by other activities that cause others to lose their memory.
Because of this karmic cause, in the future one will experience the retribution of a different kind of great element, and by its power the mind becomes deranged.
Therefore the essence of madness is not retribution, because good, evil, and other minds can all be mad. Therefore it is said that madness is born of the retribution of action.
That is, evil action attracts the retribution of irregular great elements, and the mind becomes confused and loses memory on the basis of these great elements. Therefore it is called madness.
In this way, madness and confusion should be treated in four sentences.ğŸ”½The first sentence, not confused but mad, refers to the mad person whose mind is not polluted.
The second sentence, not mad but confused, refers to the person who is not mad but whose mind is polluted.
The third sentence, mad and confused, refers to the mad person whose mind is polluted.
The fourth sentence, neither mad nor confused, refers to the person who is not mad and whose mind is not polluted.
Is the mind of sentient beings mad only because of this, or are there four other causes?
What are the four?
The first is fear, that is, nonhuman beings appear in terrifying forms and threaten, and sentient beings, seeing this, become mad.
Second, by injury, meaning due to activities that harm non-humans, etc., because of their anger, they injure their limbs, etc., and thus become mentally deranged.
There are specific joints in the bodies of sentient beings, if struck, the mind immediately becomes deranged.

Third, by conflict, meaning due to the internal wind, heat, and moisture elements of the body mutually contradicting each other, the great elements become uncomfortable and thus lead to mental derangement.
Fourth, by sorrow and grief, meaning due to the loss of loved ones, etc., sorrow and grief entangle the mind and thus lead to mental derangement, like Vasiá¹£á¹­ha and others.
What kinds of sentient beings have this mental derangement?
Except for the Uttarakuru, the other sentient beings in the desire realm may have mental derangement.
If the minds of the desire realm gods can still become deranged, how much more so for humans and evil destinies, who can be free from mental derangement?
Hell beings are always deranged, because they are oppressed by many sufferings.
The sages of the desire realm, except for the Buddhas, may have mental derangement due to the conflict of the great elements.

The minds of all tathÄgatas are free from confusion, they do not gradually abandon life, they do not have broken voices, and they do not have white hair or wrinkled faces, etc., because they are produced by extremely pure and wonderful karma.

The bodily, vocal, and mental actions that arise from hatred are called defiled actions because they are the same species as hatred.

Hatred is called defiled because when hatred is present, like a red-hot iron ball, it can burn and harm the physical and mental bodies of oneself and others wherever it touches. the bodily, vocal, and mental actions produced from hatred are called defiled because they are the cause of defilement. The effect is given the name of the cause, and therefore the World-Honored One said they are defiled.

Karmas are of four kinds: there may be karmas with black black ripening, or there may be karmas with white white ripening, or there may be karmas with black and white black and white ripening, or there may be karmas that are neither black nor white with no ripening, which can exhaust all karmas.
Although the sutra briefly shows this, it does not explain it in detail. Now it should be explained.
What are their characteristics?
The verse says:
Based on the distinctions of black-black, etc., the four kinds of karma are explained.
The bad [karma] is black in the desire realm, the good [karma] that can exhaust it is pure.
One should know that they are called black, white, both, and neither, respectively.
The treatise says:
The Buddha, based on the different natures and classes of karma and its fruits, and the distinctions between what is to be eliminated and its eliminator, explained the four kinds of black-black, etc.
All unwholesome karma is called black in one sentence, because it is endowed with defilements, is black, and is disagreeable;
its retribution is also black, because it is disagreeable.
Wholesome karma in the form realm is called white in one sense, because it is not mixed with any unwholesomeness, afflictions, or unwholesome karma;
its retribution is also white, because it is agreeable. It is not so in the formless realm, because it is often deficient.
Wholesome karma in the desire realm is called black-white, because it is mixed with evil;
its retribution is also black-white, because it is mixed with disagreeable fruits.
The terms black and white are established on the basis of the continuity of action, not on the basis of the nature of the action itself, because the two are mutually contradictory.
Evil action in the realm of desire is strong and not mixed with good, and therefore the results of evil action are said to be exclusively black.
Action that is pure and that can completely eliminate the first three kinds of action is called the fourth kind of action.
This pure action is not defiled and therefore is said to be not black. It is not favorable to the passions and therefore is said to be not white.
It does not produce white retribution and therefore is said to be not white.

Although all actions are eliminated by the holy wisdom-insight, still here the proximate antidote is spoken of.
Although bodily and verbal actions are also proximate antidotes to the three, they are not associated with wisdom, so they are not mentioned here.
Why is it that in all stages, only the final path can eliminate contaminated good actions, and not the others?
Because good dharmas are not eliminated by their own nature, because what has been eliminated may still appear in the present.
However, it is said that when the defilements that take them as objects are eliminated, those good dharmas are then said to be eliminated, because at that time the good dharmas attain disjunction.

For this reason, as long as there is still one category of defilements that take them as objects remaining, the meaning of elimination is not established, because at that time the good dharmas are still bound.

The first and third have different explanations.
Other masters say:
Karma whose results are to be experienced in hell and in the realm of desire that is to be experienced in other destinies is called, respectively, pure black karma and mixed black and white karma.
Because the retribution of hell is produced only by unwholesome karma, karma whose results are to be experienced in hell is called pure black karma.

With the exception of hell, the retributions of the other destinies of the realm of desire are produced by both wholesome and unwholesome karma, and therefore karma whose results are to be experienced in these destinies is called mixed black and white karma.
The above explanation is refuted by the following passage: Wholesome karma is not mixed with unwholesome karma.
Other masters say that
karma to be eliminated by the path of insight in the realm of desire and all other karma of the realm of desire are called, respectively, pure black karma and mixed black and white karma.

Because karma to be eliminated by the path of insight is not mixed with wholesome karma, it is called pure black karma. Because karma to be eliminated by the path of cultivation in the realm of desire is both wholesome and unwholesome, it is called mixed black and white karma.
